biogHist.abstract: The Jervis Bay Territory was surrendered by NSW to the Commonwealth in 1915 for the establishment of a sea port for the capital city. Although the Jervis Bay Territory is not geographically a part of the Australian Capital Territory the laws of the ACT apply to Jervis Bay by virtue of the Jervis Bay Acceptance Act 1915 (Cth) - so far as they are applicable and providing they are not inconsistent with an Ordinance made for the Territory. The Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community is situated in Jervis Bay Territory.
biogHist.p: As the Jervis Bay Territory comes under the jurisdiction of the ACT, legal decisions made in regards to children and their families in Jervis bay and the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community (Wreck Bay Village) remain included in the responsibilities of ACT courts. There are discussions underway however for arrangements to be changed in order for NSW to resume administration responsibilities on behalf of the Commonwealth. Challenges around issues relating to child protection have been highlighted as one of the motivations for changing arrangements.

The Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986 provided for an initial grant of 403 hectares of the territory, including Wreck Bay Village, to the local Aboriginal community. The Jervis Bay National Park and the Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens (now known as the Booderee National Park and Booderee Botanic Gardens) were granted to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community in 1995, provided they were leased back to the Director of National Parks to be managed as a national park and botanic gardens. The lease provided for a joint management plan. At this time the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community was also given a limited by-law-making power for by-laws that apply to the 403 hectares in and around Wreck Bay Village.
